image.altText: A man with a yellow checkered shirt walks outside of court surrounded by female journalists holding microphones.

props.synopsis: Terminally ill "bicycle bandit" Kym Allen Parsons will have his sentencing fast-tracked before his imminent death, and will seek access to voluntary assisted dying laws, a court hears.

title.children: Terminally ill 'bicycle bandit' to be sentenced urgently, before using voluntary assisted dying laws

image.altText: A man in a jacket and tie.

props.synopsis: South Australia's police commissioner has released a statement to "correct the public record" regarding comments made about Inspector Wade Burns.

title.children: SA police commissioner addresses 'factual inaccuracies' in public statements about inspector's alleged misconduct

image.altText: Hard of hearing, expert on cochlear

props.synopsis: A total of $2.72 million has been paid to 139 families whose children were caught up in the cochlear implant bungle at Adelaide's Women's and Children's Hospital — but the government says that does not preclude them from pursuing further legal action.

title.children: Families caught in cochlear implant bungle at Adelaide children's hospital receive $2.7 million

image.altText: A screen grab from a public health ad.

props.synopsis: Health experts have criticised a new campaign aimed at easing pressures on the state’s hospital system. The ad depicts a range of injury and illness scenarios, accompanied by the dramatic opening of Beethoven's fifth symphony.

title.children: 'Graphic' injury ad that uses Beethoven's fifth could put patients at risk, AMA says

image.altText: Split image shows profile of Anthony Albanese looking down, lips pursed, and Peter Dutton glancing up, squinting

props.synopsis: A surge in the polls helped spur the Coalition to announce its nuclear policy. Whether it holds on to that lead will come down to which side can persuade voters that such complex issues can magic up any short-term betterment in their lives.

title.children: A surge in the polls spurred the Coalition to announce its nuclear plans. Now both parties have a birthday cake problem

image.altText: People in the streets of Sydney on a wintery day all rugged up

props.synopsis: Parts of south-east Australia have recorded their coldest start to winter in decades, and another polar air mass during the coming week promises to bring strong winds, showers, small hail and alpine snow.

title.children: Polar outbreak and snow ahead this week with Sydney and Melbourne on track for coldest start to winter in decades

image.altText: A photo of Cherry Park wearing a black top, and blue and beige oversized jacket, with a dark grey backdrop.

props.synopsis: Korea's notoriously high beauty standards date back hundreds of years, and even today they influence millions of men and women, with many going to extreme lengths to fit the "toxic beauty standards".

title.children: Glass skin, doe eyes, and petite figures. Why there's a dark side to Korea's 'toxic beauty standards'

image.altText: Prince William jumps into the air with his three children as they hold hands

props.synopsis: The Princess of Wales posts an image of the Prince of Wales to social media for his birthday, showing William jumping in the air hand-in-hand with children George, Charlotte and Louis.

title.children: 'Happy birthday Papa': Kate Middleton releases photo of family on Prince William's birthday

image.altText: A woman runs her hand through her hair while on the phone

props.synopsis: Inflationary pressures are proving stubborn and the Reserve Bank does not want to push a fragile economy over the edge. So, are consumers in a better position to battle on the inflation front lines?

title.children: What a 15-minute phone call with my insurer taught me about how we're being charged

image.altText: A man wears a face mask and holds his hand up to his face in a three-finger salute

props.synopsis: Analysts say the so-called "deep state" that fringe groups fear in other parts of the world, is very real in Thailand.

title.children: Conspiracy theorists often talk about the 'deep state'. This is what one might actually look like

image.altText: A woman embracing outside of court

props.synopsis: Andrew Thomas Hayler, 38, is sentenced to nine years in jail for uploading digitally altered images of dozens of women he knew, alongside identifying details, to a pornography website.

title.children: 'He deserves it': Sydney man jailed for uploading altered photos of his friends to porn site

image.altText: Tom Hawkins clutches his left foot in agony

props.synopsis: A bad night for Geelong has been made worse as veteran forward Tom Hawkins limped off the ground in the third quarter. It comes as Carlton wrapped up a massive 63-point win a the MCG to send an ominous warning to the rest of the AFL.

title.children: Geelong 'concerned' as mystery foot issue leaves Hawkins in crutches after Carlton 'demolition'

image.altText: A man celebrates after scoring a try in a rugby league match

props.synopsis: Melbourne have defied a last-gasp effort from the Dolphins to secure a win at Lang Park in a high-scoring classic as Tevita Pangai Jnr and Ryan Papenhuyzen made their NRL returns.

title.children: Dolphins come up one metre short as Storm hang on in 54-point thriller

image.altText: Close up of paper EU flag burning on pavement.

props.synopsis: David Cameron took a colossal gamble on Brexit and lost. What followed was years of political chaos and division. With a general election approaching next month, did Brexit break Britain?

title.children: Is Brexit to blame for the UK's years of political uncertainty and chaos?

image.altText: Protesters wearing yellow headbands gather and sing songs, with many holding mobile phones aloft.

props.synopsis: The new guidelines urge Chinese institutions to defend national sovereignty, but China has no jurisdiction over Taiwan.

title.children: Taiwan slams China's threats to impose death penalty on independence activists

image.altText: Young smiling woman with long dark hair pulled back, holding a baby, whose face is blurred. both wearing brown, mustard clothes

props.synopsis: The opening day of a murder trial in the Riverina has heard Robert and Anne Geeves allegedly killed a teenager living on-and-off with them as part of a plot to gain custody of her five-month-old son.

title.children: Court told couple killed teen with intellectual disability because they 'wanted' her baby boy

image.altText: Coles and Woolworths branding outside neighbouring supermarkets

props.synopsis: The results of comparing identical groceries at different supermarkets were hardly surprising to anyone who has set foot in one in the past 18 months. How many more same-same-but-different reports will tell us what we already know?

title.children: If supermarket reports alone provided cost-of-living relief, groceries would already be cheaper at the check-out

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese Blue Room

props.synopsis: The prime minister tells an ABC host five times to "lighten up" when asked if Labor's memes mocking the Coalition's nuclear plan were juvenile.

title.children: Albanese tells critics of Labor's three-eyed nuclear memes to 'lighten up'

image.altText: An older man with grey hair and a beard smiles in a white rose garden, with a flower lapelled to his red rose-printed suit.

props.synopsis: Donald Sutherland's wry, arresting screen presence has spanned more than half a century. From The Hunger Games to M*A*S*H, here are seven of his most celebrated performances.

title.children: From The Hunger Games to M*A*S*H, here are seven of Donald Sutherland's most celebrated performances

image.altText: Donald Sutherland and Jane Fonda looking into each others eyes in the movie Klute

props.synopsis: Known for his intensity on screen, Donald Sutherland was a beloved actor. Here we look back on his varied film career that included Klute, Casanova, M*A*S*H and The Hunger Games.

title.children: Donald Sutherland's life in pictures

image.altText: seven-network-journalist-robert-ovadia delivers the news as he looks at the camera

props.synopsis: In a statement, Sydney-based crime reporter Robert Ovadia tells the ABC he had been fired after 23 years with the network.

title.children: Seven reporter Robert Ovadia 'sacked' following allegations of inappropriate behaviour

image.altText: Joe Biden speaks into a microphone, which he holds in one hand. He is holding up the other hand.

props.synopsis: If you're on social media, you might have come across a couple of viral videos this week, neither of which casts the US president in a flattering light. It's prompted the White House to fight back.

title.children: After an unflattering video of Biden went viral, the White House fought back

image.altText: Two black-and-white photographs hanging on a wall, once includes the blurred face of a person and the other includes moonlight.

props.synopsis: Amos Gebhardt's Alexis with moon, 2024 — a two-part image, or diptych, showing award-winning author Alexis Wright visible by only the light of the moon — wins this year's National Photographic Portrait Prize.

title.children: 'Sparse yet powerful' image lit only by moonlight wins National Photographic Portrait Prize 2024

image.altText: Angela Villella weras a green scarf and black and white check coat and holds a coffee cup looking out over the railway station.

props.synopsis: Reservoir residents say the government has ignored their concerns about noise and loss of privacy as trains, commuters now metres from their bedroom windows.

title.children: Angry residents confront Victorian minister as new skyrail station brings trains just metres from home

image.altText: A dirt road barred by high vis markers and a sign saying 'closed'

props.synopsis: A crime scene has been established in Gellibrand Lower after the bodies of a man and a woman were found on a walking track near Wreck Beach.

title.children: Man and woman found dead on walking track near Victoria's Great Ocean Road, police say

image.altText: A man smiling in a boxing gym holding a drink and with clenched fist

props.synopsis: A 39-year-old man has been charged over an alleged road rage attack in Western Sydney on Thursday morning which resulted in the death of Rhyce Harding.

title.children: Man charged with manslaughter as alleged Sydney road rage victim described as a 'kind soul'

image.altText: A man riding a bike in heat.

props.synopsis: Record temperatures in recent days are causing hundreds of deaths across Asia, Europe and America, as scientists warn climate change is fuelling more extreme temperature peaks.

title.children: Hundreds killed as extreme heat grips Northern Hemisphere

image.altText: A large number of naked people run or walk into a grey lake, fog hanging in the distance. The camera is positioned behind them.

props.synopsis: A record 399 Canberrans braved the morning cold for the city's eighth annual winter solstice nude swim in Lake Burley Griffin to raise money for Lifeline Canberra.

title.children: Record number of swimmers bare all to brave Canberra lake for winter solstice nude swim

image.altText: Natalie Frahm, the woman killed by an alleged shooter in South Mackay.

props.synopsis: A quiet cul-de-sac in Mackay was the scene of a shooting this week that claimed the life of Natalie Frahm — and police still don't know why.

title.children: Natalie Frahm had only lived in the quiet South Mackay cul-de-sac a short time before suffering a 'violent death'

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wears a dark suit, smiles, and shakes hands with Li Qiang who is in a black suit

props.synopsis: Now a few more details about what was (and wasn't) said behind closed doors are starting to emerge, bit by bit.

title.children: Chinese premier's visit to Australia wasn't just 'panda diplomacy,' sources say, as the PM didn't concede ground on core issues

image.altText: A leech stretches out from a leaf

props.synopsis: New video taken on the jungle floor in Madagascar may finally provide an answer to a mystery — the first "concrete" evidence of leeches jumping.

title.children: 'A graceful jump' and a 'hard landing': Video captures first evidence of leeches jumping

image.altText: An overhead shot of a large crowd of pilgrims wearing white. There is a mosque building to the left.

props.synopsis: The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade confirms an Australian is among the hundreds to die completing the Hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.

title.children: Australian among hundreds dead in Saudi Arabia on Hajj pilgrimage

image.altText: Eight Japanese senior women and their young male teacher pose in breakdancing positions in a dance studio

props.synopsis: A 74-year-old surfer and master of classical Japanese dance may seem an unlikely member of a seniors' breakdancing group, but Saruwaka Kiyoshie says getting into "breaking" was a no-brainer after it was confirmed for the 2024 Paris Games.

title.children: Inspired by Olympics debut, Japan's seniors blaze breakdancing trail
